Pillar: State Privacy Laws (CCPA/CPRA)

Pillar: State Privacy Laws (CCPA/CPRA)

1.0 Strategic Mandate

A growing patchwork of state-level data privacy laws, led by the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) and the California Privacy Rights Act (CPRA), creates new rules for handling Personal Identifiable Information (PII).

These laws grant consumers specific rights, including:

  • The Right to Know: What PII is being collected, sold, or shared.
  • The Right to Delete: The right to request the deletion of their PII.
  • The Right to Opt-Out: The right to direct a business not to sell or share their PII.

This primarily impacts lead generation and marketing automation.

2.0 Operational Mandates (Non-Negotiable)

Requirement Standard Operating Procedure (SOP)
1. Update Privacy Policy SOP: The agency website must have a clear and conspicuous Privacy Policy. <br> Action: This policy must be updated to include the specific rights granted by laws like CCPA/CPRA, including a "Do Not Sell or Share My Personal Information" link and a clear description of the data you collect (e.g., from lead forms) and why.
2. Honor Deletion Requests SOP: The agency must have a documented, verifiable process for honoring a consumer's "Right to Delete" request. <br> Action: This process must be completed within the law's required timeframe (e.g., 45 days) and must be logged in a compliance tracker. Note: This right may be superseded by the 10-year CMS/HIPAA retention mandates.
3. Honor Opt-Out Requests SOP: The "Do Not Sell or Share" link on the website must lead to a functional form. <br> Action: When a request is received, the consumer's PII (e.g., lead data) must be immediately flagged in the CRM and excluded from all future sales, sharing, or marketing lists.
4. Data Minimization SOP: Only collect the PII that is absolutely necessary. <br> Action: Audit all lead generation forms. Do not ask for sensitive information (like SSN or detailed health info) on an initial, unsecured web form. Collect this data securely after consent is established.
